bibl.title: Letter from Theodore C. Lyster to E.C. Houle, February 2, 1923

div1.p: Lyster praises Houle and the yellow fever work in Mexico and congratulates him on the birth of a son. Lyster informs Houle that he sent a copy of the report on the yellow fever work to Carter.

div1.head: Letter from Theodore C. Lyster to E.C. Houle, February 2, 1923
div1.opener:
February 2nd, 1923.
Dr. E. C. Houle,
Chief of the 5th Zone,
Chief Surgeon F.C. S.P. de M.
Empalme, Sonora, Mexico.
My Dear Doctor Houle:-
div1.p:
Shortly after the article on the work your and
Harris did on fish and mosquitoes arrived I was called East suddenly
because of the illness of my mother. I am glad to say that I found
her improving and was able to return very greatly relieved.

Much as I appreciate this copy I feel it is too
valuable to have it not carry further its message, and I am, therefore,
sending this copy to Dr. H. P. Carter, who is busily engaged in writing
up the history of Yellow Fever for the Foundation. Not only will he
appreciate it but will really be able to make use of its contents.

I note that you state there is a negligable amount
of stegynomia breeding north of Mazatlan between December and May, which
means a great deal in clearing this area each winter of Yellow Fever.
There is too much data for me to just attempt to analyse it in a letter
of appreciation. My congratulations to you both, with the hope that
you have seen the last of Yellow Fever. But, of course, I am still
anxious in regard to Zone No. 1 and I hope by intensive work this dry
season that this area will be cleaned up. only by the hardest sort of
work will this be possible.

Let me also congratulate you and Mrs. Houle on
the arrival of a boy. I was talking to Dr. Sturgeon a few days ago
and he was the one who told me the good news. Best wishes to you
both.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, T. C. Lyster, M. D. TCL/D.
Encl.
